metadata.title: Multitasking | Apple Developer Documentation

metadata.summary: This Apple Human Interface Guidelines document provides comprehensive guidance on implementing multitasking in apps across all Apple platforms. It covers best practices for handling app switching, audio interruptions, background tasks, and platform-specific considerations for iOS, iPadOS, macOS, tvOS, and visionOS.

content.text: Multitasking
Multitasking lets people switch quickly from one app to another, performing tasks in each.

content.description: A stylized orange/amber colored icon featuring two overlapping rectangles representing app windows or multitasking. The rectangles are arranged diagonally with a 3D effect, suggesting layered windows. The icon has rounded corners and uses a gradient from light orange to darker amber/orange tones.
content.composition: Two rectangles overlapping at an angle, positioned in center of icon container, with slight 3D perspective
content.technicalDetails: SF Symbol or custom Apple HIG icon representing multitasking concept
content.contextualRelevance: Visual representation of the multitasking concept - multiple app windows layered

content.text: People expect to use multitasking on their devices, and they may think something is wrong if your app doesn't allow it. With rare exceptions — such as some games, and Apple Vision Pro apps running in a Full Space — every app needs to work well with multitasking.
In addition to app switching, multitasking can present different experiences on different devices; see Platform considerations.

A great multitasking experience helps people accomplish tasks in multiple apps by managing content in a variety of simultaneous contexts. Because you don't know when people will initiate multitasking, your app or game always needs to be prepared to save and restore their context.
Best practices

Pause activities that require people's attention or active participation when they switch away. If your app is a game or a media-viewing app, for example, make sure people don't miss anything when they switch to another app. When they switch back, let them continue as if they never left.

emphasis.boldText: Pause activities that require people's attention or active participation when they switch away.

content.text: Respond smoothly to audio interruptions. Occasionally, audio from another app or the system itself may interrupt your app's audio. For example, an incoming phone call or a music playlist initiated by Siri might interrupt your app's audio. When situations like these occur, people expect your app to respond in the following ways:

items.text: Pause audio indefinitely for primary audio interruptions, such as playing music, podcasts, or audiobooks.
Temporarily lower the volume or pause the audio for shorter interruptions, such as GPS directional notifications, and resume the original volume or playback when the interruption ends.

content.text: For guidance, see Playing audio.

Finish user-initiated tasks in the background. When someone starts a task like downloading assets or processing a video file, they expect it to finish even if they switch away from your app. If your app is in the middle of performing a task that doesn't need additional input, complete it in the background before suspending.

emphasis.boldText: Finish user-initiated tasks in the background.

content.text: Use notifications sparingly. Your app can send notifications when it's suspended or running in the background. If people start an important or time-sensitive task in your app, and then switch away from it, they might appreciate receiving a notification when the task completes so they can switch back to your app and take the next step. In contrast, people don't generally need to know the moment a routine or secondary task completes. In this scenario, avoid sending an unnecessary notification; instead, let people check on the task when they return to your app. For guidance, see Managing notifications.
Not supported in watchOS.
Platform considerations
iOS
On iPhone, multitasking lets people use FaceTime or watch a video in Picture in Picture while they also use a different app.

content.description: iPhone screenshot showing the App Switcher interface. The screen displays multiple app cards arranged in a horizontal stack, showing apps like Maps with a map view displaying San Francisco area, and other apps. Each app card shows a preview of the app's current state. The app cards are slightly overlapping and arranged in a carousel-style layout. The status bar shows time '9:41' and typical iPhone status indicators. Background is dark/black.
content.composition: Vertical iPhone screenshot with app cards arranged horizontally in carousel format
content.technicalDetails: iOS App Switcher, iPhone device frame, status bar visible at 9:41
textInImage: Various app names and UI labels
content.contextualRelevance: Demonstrates iOS app switcher functionality for multitasking

content.text: The app switcher displays all currently open apps.

content.description: iPhone screenshot showing Picture in Picture functionality with FaceTime. The main screen displays the Maps application showing a detailed street map of what appears to be San Francisco with street names, landmarks, and navigation UI. In the top-right corner, there is a small floating FaceTime video window (Picture in Picture) showing a person's video call. The PiP window has rounded corners and appears to float above the main content. The status bar shows '9:41' and typical iOS indicators including a green indicator for active camera/microphone.
content.composition: Full-screen Maps app with small PiP FaceTime window floating in top-right corner
content.technicalDetails: iOS Maps app with FaceTime PiP overlay, shows active video call while navigating
content.contextualRelevance: Demonstrates FaceTime Picture in Picture functionality allowing video calls while using other apps

content.text: A current FaceTime call can continue while people use another app.
iPadOS

On iPad, people can view and interact with the windows of several different apps at the same time. An individual app can also support multiple open windows, which lets people view and interact with more than one window in the same app at one time.
People can use iPad with either full-screen or windowed apps. When full screen, apps occupy the full screen, and people can switch between individual app windows using the app switcher.

content.description: iPad screenshot showing full-screen multitasking with two apps in Split View configuration. On the left side (approximately 50% width) is the Photos app displaying a grid of landscape photographs including nature scenes, mountains, and outdoor imagery. On the right side (approximately 50% width) is the Notes app showing a note titled 'Big Sur trip itinerary' with text content including dates and planning information. The split is clearly defined with a thin divider line between the two apps. The iPad status bar is visible at the top showing the time and system indicators. The dock is visible at the bottom of the screen.
content.composition: Horizontal split with two apps side by side, equal width, full height
content.technicalDetails: iPadOS Split View with 50/50 split, full-screen mode, landscape orientation
content.contextualRelevance: Demonstrates iPadOS full-screen Split View multitasking with two apps

content.text: When using windowed apps, app windows are resizable, and people can arrange them to suit their needs with behavior similar to macOS. The system provides window controls for common tiling configurations, entering full screen, minimizing, and closing windows. The system identifies the frontmost window by coloring its window controls and casting a drop shadow on windows behind it. For guidance, see Windows > iPadOS.

content.description: iPad screenshot showing windowed multitasking mode with multiple overlapping app windows on a desktop-like interface. The background shows a nature wallpaper with autumn/fall colors (orange, yellow leaves). Multiple app windows are visible: Safari browser window in the foreground showing a webpage, Notes app window behind it, and possibly other app windows. Each window has macOS-style window controls (red/yellow/green traffic light buttons) in the top-left corner. The windows cast drop shadows on each other to show depth and layering. The frontmost window has more prominent colored window controls while background windows have grayed-out controls. The iPad dock is visible at the bottom of the screen.
content.composition: Overlapping windows in cascading arrangement, frontmost window in focus with vibrant controls
content.mood: Desktop productivity, macOS-like experience on iPad
content.technicalDetails: iPadOS windowed mode (Stage Manager style), multiple resizable windows with traffic light controls
content.contextualRelevance: Demonstrates iPadOS windowed app mode with macOS-like window management

content.text: Additionally, videos and FaceTime calls can also play in a Picture in Picture overlay above other content regardless of whether apps are full screen or windowed.

content.label: Note
content.text: Apps don't control multitasking configurations or receive any indication of the ones that people choose.

To help your app respond correctly when people open it while windowed, make sure it adapts gracefully to different screen sizes. For guidance, see Layout and Windows; for developer guidance, see Multitasking on iPad, Mac, and Apple Vision Pro. To learn more about how people use iPad multitasking features, see Use multitasking on your iPad.

links.text: Multitasking on iPad, Mac, and Apple Vision Pro

content.text: macOS

On Mac, multitasking is the default experience because people typically run more than one app at a time, switching between windows and tasks as they work. When multiple app windows are open, macOS applies drop shadows that make the windows appear layered on the desktop, and applies other visual effects to help people distinguish different window states; for guidance, see macOS window states.
tvOS
On Apple TV, people can play or browse content while also playing movies or TV shows in Picture in Picture (where supported).
visionOS
On Apple Vision Pro, people can run multiple apps at the same time in the Shared Space, viewing and switching between windows and volumes throughout the space.

Only one window is active at a time in the Shared Space. When people look from one window to another, the window they're currently looking at becomes active while the previous window becomes more translucent and appears to recede along the z-axis. Closing an app window in the Shared Space transitions the app to the background without quitting it.

content.label: Note
content.text: When an app is the Now Playing app, closing its window automatically pauses audio playback; if people want to resume playback, they can do so in Control Center without opening the window.

Avoid interfering with the system-provided multitasking behavior. When people look from one window to another, visionOS applies a feathered mask to the window they look away from to clarify its changed state. To avoid interfering with this visual feedback, don't change the appearance of a window's edges.

emphasis.boldText: Avoid interfering with the system-provided multitasking behavior.

content.description: Video player element with Play button, demonstrating visionOS multitasking behavior

content.text: Don't pause a window's video playback when people look away from it. In visionOS, as in macOS, people expect the playback they start in one window to continue while they view or perform a task in another window.

emphasis.boldText: Don't pause a window's video playback when people look away from it.

content.text: Be prepared for situations where your audio can duck. Unless an app is currently the Now Playing app, its audio can duck when people look away from it to another app.

emphasis.boldText: Be prepared for situations where your audio can duck.

pages.pageSummary: This is the complete Apple Human Interface Guidelines documentation page for Multitasking. It provides comprehensive guidance on implementing multitasking across all Apple platforms (iOS, iPadOS, macOS, tvOS, visionOS, watchOS). The page includes best practices for handling app switching, audio interruptions, background tasks, and notifications. Platform-specific considerations are detailed with screenshots demonstrating iOS app switcher and Picture in Picture, iPadOS Split View and windowed modes, and visionOS Shared Space behavior. The document was last updated June 9, 2025 with reorganized iPadOS guidance.

semanticStructure.documentFlow: The document begins with an introduction emphasizing the importance of multitasking support in apps. It then presents best practices applicable across all platforms, covering activity pausing, audio handling, background tasks, and notifications. The platform considerations section provides specific guidance for each Apple platform, progressing from iOS (simplest) through iPadOS (most detailed with multiple screenshots) to macOS, tvOS, and visionOS (spatial computing specific). The document concludes with resources for further learning and a change log tracking document updates.

keyTerms.definition: The ability to switch quickly from one app to another, performing tasks in each, including app switching and platform-specific features like Picture in Picture and Split View
A feature that allows video or FaceTime calls to continue playing in a small floating window while using other apps
An iPadOS multitasking mode where two apps are displayed side by side, each occupying part of the screen
A system interface that displays all currently open apps as cards, allowing users to quickly switch between them
The default visionOS environment where multiple apps can run simultaneously with windows and volumes positioned throughout the spatial environment
A visionOS mode where a single app takes over the entire spatial environment, an exception to standard multitasking behavior
Temporarily lowering audio volume during interruptions, then restoring original volume when the interruption ends
iPadOS mode where apps appear in resizable, overlapping windows similar to macOS, with traffic light window controls
The app currently designated as the audio source for the system, affecting audio ducking behavior in visionOS
In visionOS, the depth dimension along which inactive windows recede to indicate their non-active state

keyFindings: Every app should support multitasking with rare exceptions (some games, visionOS Full Space apps)
Apps must save and restore context at any time since multitasking can be initiated unpredictably
Games and media apps should pause when users switch away to prevent missed content
Audio interruptions require different handling: indefinite pause for primary audio, temporary ducking for short interruptions
User-initiated background tasks should complete even when the app is backgrounded
Notifications should be used sparingly - only for important or time-sensitive task completions
iPadOS supports both full-screen (Split View) and windowed (Stage Manager-like) multitasking modes
Apps cannot control or detect which multitasking configuration users choose
visionOS uses gaze-based window activation where looking at a window makes it active
In visionOS, closing a window backgrounds the app without quitting it
macOS multitasking is the default experience with persistent multiple windows
Apps should not interfere with system-provided multitasking visual feedback (feathered masks, drop shadows)

shortInterruptions.behavior: Temporarily lower volume or pause, resume when interruption ends

designDecisions.decision: Pause attention-requiring activities on app switch
designDecisions.rationale: Users should not miss content when switching apps, ensuring seamless experience when returning
Users expect downloads and processing to finish regardless of app state

designDecisions.decision: Use notifications sparingly for background tasks
designDecisions.rationale: Only important/time-sensitive completions warrant interruption; routine tasks should be checked manually

designDecisions.decision: Don't pause video on gaze shift in visionOS
designDecisions.rationale: Consistency with macOS behavior where video continues in background windows

designDecisions.decision: Prepare for audio ducking in visionOS
designDecisions.rationale: Non-Now Playing apps will have audio automatically lowered when users look away

designDecisions.decision: Avoid modifying window edge appearance in visionOS
designDecisions.rationale: System applies feathered mask for state feedback; custom edges would interfere

designDecisions.decision: Adapt gracefully to screen size changes
designDecisions.rationale: Windowed iPadOS apps can be resized; apps must handle various sizes
